Implicit Dynamical Flow Fusion (IDFF) for Generative Modeling

Mohammad R. Rezaei Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Toronto Rahul G. Krishnan Vector Institute Department of Computer Science, University of Toronto Milos R. Popovic Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Toronto KITE Research Institute, Toronto Rehabilitation Institute Milad Lankarany Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Toronto KITE Research Institute, Toronto Rehabilitation Institute
Abstract

Conditional Flow Matching (CFM) models can generate high-quality samples from a non-informative prior but they can be slow, often needing hundreds of network evaluations (NFE). To address this, we propose Implicit Dynamical Flow Fusion (IDFF); IDFF learns a new vector field with an additional momentum term that enables taking longer steps during sample generation while maintaining the fidelity of the generated distribution. Consequently, IDFFs reduce the NFEs by a factor of ten (relative to CFMs) without sacrificing sample quality, enabling rapid sampling and efficient handling of image and time-series data generation tasks. We evaluate IDFF on standard benchmarks such as CIFAR-10 and CelebA for image generation. We achieved comparable likelihood and quality performance to CFMs and diffusion-based models with many fewer NFEs. IDFF also shows superior performance on time-series datasets modeling, including molecular simulation and sea surface temperature (SST) datasets, highlighting its versatility and effectiveness across different domains.

1 Introduction

Diffusion models (Ho et al., 2020; Cachay et al., 2023; Myers et al., 2022) have gained significant traction in modeling complex, high-dimensional data by iteratively transforming random noise into meaningful data. These models have been successfully applied in diverse fields, such as generating high-quality images (Song et al., 2020a) and text (Liu et al., 2024; Kim et al., 2019). However, the training process is computationally intensive, requiring numerous steps of sampling (Ho et al., 2020; Song et al., 2020b). Specifically, diffusion models require hundreds of function evaluations (NFEs) to achieve high-quality results. Techniques such as DPM-solver (Lu et al., 2022a, b) and Denoising Diffusion Implicit Models (DDIMs) (Song et al., 2020b) address help reduce the NFE for diffusion-based generative models. While diffusion models parameterize the dynamics that transform noise into data, Conditional Flow Matching (CFMs) (Li et al., 2022; Tong et al., 2023; Liu et al., 2022; Albergo and Vanden-Eijnden, 2022; Albergo et al., 2023) directly parameterize vector fields that govern transformation from noise to data. CFMs define conditional probability paths through the change of variable theory in statistics (Lipman et al., 2022), enabling faster convergence during training compared to diffusion models (Lipman et al., 2022).

Generating high-quality samples with CFMs requires hundreds of NFEs; this makes the process computationally expensive (Dao et al., 2023; Lipman et al., 2022) and restricts the extension of CFM models to time-series data modeling since the NFE scale with the length of the sequence.

To overcome these challenges, we introduce a novel method to improve the efficiency of CFMs, allowing for longer sampling steps without compromising the fidelity of the target distribution. Our approach is inspired by Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) algorithms (Neal et al., 2011; Neal, 2012), which utilize the conservation properties of Hamiltonian dynamics to couple the target and momentum variables.

The contributions of our work are as follows:

  1. 1.

    We propose the Implicit Dynamical Flow Fusion (IDFF), which integrates a momentum term into the vector field of conditional flow models. Similar to how HMC reduces the number of samples required to reach the target distribution (Neal, 2012; Hoffman et al., 2014), IDFF reduces the NFE by a factor of 10 compared to traditional CFMs while maintaining identical marginal distributions. Additionally, we introduce a training objective that directly aligns the generated samples with the actual data rather than solely focusing on matching the conditional flows.

  2. 2.

    We validate IDFF through extensive experiments on image generation using datasets such as CIFAR-10 and CelebA. Additional results on ImageNet-64, CelebA-HQ, LSUN-Church, and LSUN-Bedroom are presented in Figure 1. Our models achieve a superior balance between computational cost and sample quality compared to both traditional diffusion models (e.g., DDPM (Ho et al., 2020), DDIM (Song et al., 2020b)) and current CFMs (Pooladian et al., 2023; Tong et al., 2023).

  3. 3.

    We show that reducing NFEs makes IDFF practical for other generation tasks, such as time-series modeling. We demonstrate IDFF’s effectiveness in capturing complex dynamical systems, including 3D attractors, molecular dynamics (MD), and sea surface temperatures (SST). Our results indicate that IDFF surpasses other methods regarding sample quality for MD and SST datasets while maintaining computational efficiency, with NFE ≤\leq 5 for each generated sample.

2 Background

Score-based generative models

Score-based models (Song et al., 2020b; Song and Ermon, 2019) represent a broad class of diffusion models that describe a continuous-time stochastic process. These models are characterized by a stochastic process 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡{\mathbf{x}}_{t}, which is governed by the following Ito equation:

d​𝐱=f​(𝐱,t)​d​t+g​(t)​d​𝐰,𝑑𝐱𝑓𝐱𝑡𝑑𝑡𝑔𝑡𝑑𝐰d{\mathbf{x}}=f({\mathbf{x}},t)dt+g(t)d{\mathbf{w}}, (1)

Where t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1], f​(⋅,t):ℝd→ℝd:𝑓⋅𝑡→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑f(\cdot,t):\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d}, and g​(⋅):ℝ→ℝ:𝑔⋅→ℝℝg(\cdot):\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} represent the drift and diffusion coefficients, respectively, and 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑{\mathbf{w}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is a standard Wiener process.

The time-reversed version of this diffusion process, obtained from the Fokker–Planck equations(Song et al., 2020b), is also a diffusion process. This reverse-time stochastic SDE is defined as:

d​𝐱=(f​(𝐱,t)−g​(t)2​∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐱))​d​t+g​(t)​d​𝐰¯,𝑑𝐱𝑓𝐱𝑡𝑔superscript𝑡2subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱𝑑𝑡𝑔𝑡𝑑¯𝐰d{\mathbf{x}}=\left(f({\mathbf{x}},t)-g(t)^{2}\nabla_{{\mathbf{x}}}\log p_{t}({\mathbf{x}})\right)dt+g(t)d\bar{{\mathbf{w}}}, (2)

where 𝐰¯¯𝐰\bar{{\mathbf{w}}} is a standard Wiener process. Equation 2 produces the same marginal distributions as the forward diffusion process defined by Equation 1 (Song et al., 2020b).

To sample from this SDE, one must solve Equation 2, beginning with random noise as the initial condition, as demonstrated by (Ho et al., 2020) 𝐱0∼𝒩​(0,𝐈)similar-tosubscript𝐱0𝒩0𝐈{\mathbf{x}}_{0}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\mathbf{I}), and gradually converges to the data distribution pdatasubscript𝑝datap_{\mathrm{data}} by time t=1𝑡1t=1 (Song et al., 2020a). The score-matching approach enables this by choosing f​(𝐱,t)=h​(t)​𝐱𝑓𝐱𝑡ℎ𝑡𝐱f({\mathbf{x}},t)=h(t){\mathbf{x}}, a fixed affine transformation of 𝐱𝐱{\mathbf{x}}, while learning ∇𝐱log⁡pt​(𝐱)subscript∇𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱\nabla_{{\mathbf{x}}}\log p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}) through a score-matching loss (Ho et al., 2020).

Conditional flow matching as a generative model

A CFM model (Lipman et al., 2022) defines a time-dependent vector field 𝐯tsubscript𝐯𝑡{\mathbf{v}}_{t} parameterized by a neural network that creates a conditional flow, ϕt(⋅|𝐱1):ℝd→ℝd\phi_{t}(\cdot|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}):\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d}, defined by an ODE:

dd​t​ϕt​(𝐱|𝐱1)=𝐯t​(ϕt​(𝐱|𝐱1))𝑑𝑑𝑡subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1subscript𝐯𝑡subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1\frac{d}{dt}\phi_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})={\mathbf{v}}_{t}(\phi_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})) (3)

with an initial condition ϕ0​(𝐱0|𝐱1)=𝐱0subscriptitalic-ϕ0conditionalsubscript𝐱0subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱0\phi_{0}({\mathbf{x}}_{0}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})={\mathbf{x}}_{0}. A CFM uses a continuous normalizing flow (CNF) to transform a simple prior density p0subscript𝑝0p_{0} (e.g., pure noise) into a more complex one, p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}, using the push-forward equation:

pt=p0(ϕt−1(𝐱|𝐱1))|det[∂ϕt−1∂𝐱(𝐱|𝐱1)]|p_{t}=p_{0}(\phi_{t}^{-1}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}))\left|\textbf{det}\left[\frac{\partial\phi_{t}^{-1}}{\partial{\mathbf{x}}}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})\right]\right| (4)

Therefore, a generative conditional vector field represents a conditional probability density path pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}), a time-dependent probability density function for t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1], generated by a vector field 𝐯^t​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript^𝐯𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}). Here, p0subscript𝑝0p_{0} is a simple prior distribution, and p1≈pd​a​t​asubscript𝑝1subscript𝑝𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎p_{1}\approx p_{data}. Given a target conditional probability density path pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}) and a corresponding conditional vector field 𝐯^t​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript^𝐯𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}), which generates pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}), we can define the CFM objective:

ℒCFM(θ)=𝔼t,𝐱1,𝐱t∥𝐯t(𝐱t)−𝐯^t(𝐱t|𝐱1)∥2\mathcal{L}_{\text{CFM}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{t,{\mathbf{x}}_{1},{\mathbf{x}}_{t}}\big{\|}{\mathbf{v}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t})-\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})\big{\|}^{2} (5)

where t∼𝒰​[0,1]similar-to𝑡𝒰01t\sim{\mathcal{U}}[0,1], 𝐱1∼pd​a​t​asimilar-tosubscript𝐱1subscript𝑝𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎{\mathbf{x}}_{1}\sim p_{data}, and 𝐱t∼pt​(𝐱t|𝐱1)similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝑝𝑡conditionalsubscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐱1{\mathbf{x}}_{t}\sim p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}). The training objective defined in 5 guarantees that the marginalized 𝐯^t​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript^𝐯𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}), 𝐯^t​(𝐱)subscript^𝐯𝑡𝐱\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}), generates pt​(𝐱)subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}) as FM models do, and thus allows easy sampling of unbiased estimates as long as we can efficiently sample from pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}) and compute 𝐯^t​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript^𝐯𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}), both of which can be done as they are defined on a per-sample basis (Lipman et al., 2022).

CFMs share conceptual similarities with diffusion models, as both frameworks rely on defining continuous probability paths over time. While diffusion models use stochastic processes to transform data distributions, typically governed by an SDE as seen in (Song et al., 2020b; Ho et al., 2020), CFMs utilize a deterministic vector field to create a conditional flow that directly maps an initial prior distribution to the target distribution via an ODE. Diffusion models, such as denoising score matching models, rely on stochastic diffusion paths to approximate the data distribution. At the same time, CFMs bypass this stochastic process by constructing a conditional vector field and sampling from an ODE to generate samples (Lipman et al., 2022; Song et al., 2020a).

The CFM objective defined in Equation 5 appears simple. However, it is nearly intractable due to the absence of prior knowledge regarding an appropriate coupling term between the initial (p0subscript𝑝0p_{0}) and target (p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}) distributions. To address this challenge, optimal transport (OT) (Pooladian et al., 2023; Lipman et al., 2022) is used to couple the initial and target distributions. This term seeks a mapping from p0subscript𝑝0p_{0} to p1subscript𝑝1p_{1} that minimizes the displacement cost between these two distributions, resulting in flows that can be integrated accurately. This CFM variant is Optimal Transport CFMs (OT-CFMs)(Tong et al., 2023). Although OT improves the efficiency of training in CFMs, as shown in Figure 2, traditional sampling methods for OT-CFMs still require more than a hundred function evaluations (NFE) to generate high-quality samples (Dao et al., 2023; Tong et al., 2023).

As shown in Pooladian et al. (2023), the vector field associated with the conditional vector field 𝐯^t​(𝐱t|𝐱1)=𝐱1−𝐱1−tsubscript^𝐯𝑡conditionalsubscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱1𝐱1𝑡\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})=\frac{{\mathbf{x}}_{1}-{\mathbf{x}}}{1-t} can be expressed as 𝐯^t​(𝐱t|𝐱1)=𝐱1−𝐱0subscript^𝐯𝑡conditionalsubscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱0\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})={\mathbf{x}}_{1}-{\mathbf{x}}_{0}. It becomes a deterministic function when conditioned on 𝐱0subscript𝐱0{\mathbf{x}}_{0}. Consequently, using any deterministic solver and conditioning on the initial points 𝐱0subscript𝐱0{\mathbf{x}}_{0}, the sample generation process becomes deterministic, which limits the generalizability of the conditional OT-CFM models compared to the stochastic processes employed in denoising diffusion models. Moreover, as flow matching learns 𝐯^t​(𝐱t|𝐱1)subscript^𝐯𝑡conditionalsubscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐱1\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}), there is no flexibility in the sampling steps during the training phase. This restriction on sampling, constrained to the integration steps, hinders the ability of OT-CFMs to generate high-quality samples with a small number of integration steps, often leading to a high NFE during the sampling process.

3 Implicit dynamical flow fusion model (IDFF)

Increasing the sampling steps to improve generative efficiency in FMs while preserving the target distribution’s accuracy is crucial. To achieve this, we introduce a learnable Hamiltonian momentum term, denoted as 𝝃tsubscript𝝃𝑡\bm{\xi}_{t}, into the vector field 𝐯^tsubscript^𝐯𝑡\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t} and define a new vector field for FMs as:

𝐯~t​(𝐱)=1−σt2​𝐯^t​(𝐱)+σt2​𝝃t,subscript~𝐯𝑡𝐱1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑡subscript^𝐯𝑡𝐱subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑡subscript𝝃𝑡\tilde{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}})=\sqrt{1-\sigma^{2}_{t}}\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}})+\sigma^{2}_{t}\bm{\xi}_{t}, (6)

where the marginal vector field 𝐯^t​(𝐱)subscript^𝐯𝑡𝐱\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}), associated with the conditional vector field 𝐯^t​(𝐱t|𝐱1)subscript^𝐯𝑡conditionalsubscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐱1\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}), generates the marginal probability path pt​(𝐱)subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}) of these conditionals and σt=σ0​t​(1−t)subscript𝜎𝑡subscript𝜎0𝑡1𝑡\sigma_{t}=\sigma_{0}\sqrt{t(1-t)}. We define the momentum term 𝝃t=γ​∇xlog⁡pt​(𝐱t)subscript𝝃𝑡𝛾subscript∇𝑥subscript𝑝𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡\bm{\xi}_{t}=\gamma\nabla_{x}\log p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}) to guide the vector field towards the gradients of the log probability of samples 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡{\mathbf{x}}_{t}, using a weight factor γ𝛾\gamma, as depicted in Figure 2.

When σtsubscript𝜎𝑡\sigma_{t} is set sufficiently close to 0 for t={0,1}𝑡01t=\{0,1\}, 𝐯~t​(𝐱)subscript~𝐯𝑡𝐱\tilde{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}) converges to the standard 𝐯^t​(𝐱)subscript^𝐯𝑡𝐱\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}), ensuring the same marginal distributions at t=0𝑡0t=0 and t=1𝑡1t=1 as in CFMs. As demonstrated here, incorporating such an auxiliary variable into Langevin sampling methods aligns with well-established HMC simulated sampling methods. This strategy reduces the steps required to achieve a high-fidelity distribution Hoffman et al. (2014); Neal (2012).

By substituting the new conditional vector field 𝐯~t​(𝐱)subscript~𝐯𝑡𝐱\tilde{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}), defined in equation 6, in the continuity equation as described in Appendix A.1.1, we introduce the vector field 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡{\mathbf{w}}_{t}, which defines the IDFF (Implicit Dynamical Flow Fusion) probability flow ODE as:

𝐰t=𝐯~t​(𝐱)−σt22​∇log⁡pt​(𝐱t)=1−σt2​𝐯^t​(𝐱)+(2​γ−1)2​σt2​∇log⁡pt​(𝐱t),subscript𝐰𝑡subscript~𝐯𝑡𝐱superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑡22∇subscript𝑝𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑡2subscript^𝐯𝑡𝐱2𝛾12superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑡2∇subscript𝑝𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡{\mathbf{w}}_{t}=\tilde{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}})-\frac{\sigma_{t}^{2}}{2}\nabla\log p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t})=\sqrt{1-\sigma_{t}^{2}}\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}})+\frac{(2\gamma-1)}{2}\sigma_{t}^{2}\nabla\log p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}), (7)

where the conditional process starts with the initial condition 𝐱0∼𝒩​(0,I)similar-tosubscript𝐱0𝒩0I{\mathbf{x}}_{0}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\textbf{I}) and follows a specific conditional probability path pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}) to ultimately generate 𝐱1subscript𝐱1{\mathbf{x}}_{1}.

Lemma 1.

Given that 𝐯^t​(𝐱)subscript^𝐯𝑡𝐱\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}) represents the vector field that generates pt​(𝐱)subscript𝑝𝑡𝐱p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}) and σtsubscript𝜎𝑡\sigma_{t} is set sufficiently close to 0 for t={0,1}𝑡01t=\{0,1\}. The IDFF probability flow ODE defined in equation 7 follows the same marginal distribution as the CFMs with the ODE defined in equation 3.

3.1 Training Objective for IDFF

As the CFM literature outlines, learning a conditional vector field 𝐯^t​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript^𝐯𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}) is faster and preserves the same marginals. Consequently, we can define the conditional probability OT path pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}) to act as a probability bridge between a source point 𝐱0subscript𝐱0{\mathbf{x}}_{0} and a target point 𝐱1subscript𝐱1{\mathbf{x}}_{1} (Tong et al., 2023; Lipman et al., 2022).

An efficient approach to selecting the probability path pt(.)p_{t}(.) from a displacement perspective is to choose the path with minimal displacement between p0(.)p_{0}(.) and p1(.)p_{1}(.) by defining it as a stochastic interpolator between 𝐱1subscript𝐱1{\mathbf{x}}_{1} and 𝐱0subscript𝐱0{\mathbf{x}}_{0}, given by:

pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)=𝒩​(𝐱∣t​𝐱1+(1−t)​𝐱0,σt2​I),σt=σ0​t​(1−t)formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1𝒩conditional𝐱𝑡subscript𝐱11𝑡subscript𝐱0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑡2Isubscript𝜎𝑡subscript𝜎0𝑡1𝑡p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})=\mathcal{N}({\mathbf{x}}\mid t{\mathbf{x}}_{1}+(1-t){\mathbf{x}}_{0},\sigma_{t}^{2}\textbf{I}),\ \ \sigma_{t}=\sigma_{0}\sqrt{t(1-t)} (8)
𝐯^t​(𝐱|𝐱1)=𝐱1−𝐱1−tsubscript^𝐯𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱1𝐱1𝑡\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})=\frac{{\mathbf{x}}_{1}-{\mathbf{x}}}{1-t} (9)

This definition aligns with the conditional OT paths between 𝐱1subscript𝐱1{\mathbf{x}}_{1} and 𝐱0subscript𝐱0{\mathbf{x}}_{0}, which have an equivalent conditional probability flow to the marginal pt(.)p_{t}(.) of flow 𝐯^t(.)\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}(.) (Pooladian et al., 2023).

For large datasets, computing this OT map can be challenging (Cuturi, 2013; Tong et al., 2020). A minibatch approximation of OT, similar to (Fatras et al., 2021), can address this. While minibatch OT introduces some errors compared to the exact OT solution, it has proven effective in numerous applications such as domain adaptation and generative modeling (Genevay et al., 2018). Therefore, we use minibatch OT to approximate the map between 𝐱0subscript𝐱0{\mathbf{x}}_{0} and 𝐱1subscript𝐱1{\mathbf{x}}_{1}.

Current CFM objectives utilize the loss function defined in equation 5, which optimizes the prediction of the vector field. Instead of directly learning 𝐯^t​(𝐱∣𝐱1;θ)subscript^𝐯𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1𝜃\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}\mid{\mathbf{x}}_{1};\theta) using equation 5, we propose defining a denoising neural network 𝐱^1​(𝐱,t;θ)subscript^𝐱1𝐱𝑡𝜃\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta) and reparameterizing 𝐯^t​(𝐱∣𝐱1;θ)subscript^𝐯𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1𝜃\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}\mid{\mathbf{x}}_{1};\theta) as follows:

𝐯^t​(𝐱∣𝐱1;θ)=𝐱^1​(𝐱,t;θ)−𝐱1−tsubscript^𝐯𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1𝜃subscript^𝐱1𝐱𝑡𝜃𝐱1𝑡\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}\mid{\mathbf{x}}_{1};\theta)=\frac{\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta)-{\mathbf{x}}}{1-t} (10)

We suggest a loss function comprising two terms: the first term directly optimizes the denoising model 𝐱^1​(𝐱,t;θ)subscript^𝐱1𝐱𝑡𝜃\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta), with 𝐱𝐱{\mathbf{x}} as the noisy input, and the second term is a scoring model that approximates ∇xlog⁡pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript∇𝑥subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1\nabla_{x}\log p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}). Optimizing 𝐱^1​(𝐱,t;θ)subscript^𝐱1𝐱𝑡𝜃\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta) and ϵ​(𝐱,t;θ)italic-ϵ𝐱𝑡𝜃\epsilon({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta) directly implies optimizing the vector field 𝐯~t​(𝐱∣𝐱1;θ)subscript~𝐯𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1𝜃\tilde{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}\mid{\mathbf{x}}_{1};\theta), which is the intuition behind naming the IDFF model as an implicit model.

Considering that both 𝐱^1​(𝐱,t;θ)subscript^𝐱1𝐱𝑡𝜃\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta) and pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}) are easy to sample from, we can use neural networks to approximate both and train them with the following loss function:

ℒIDFF(θ)=𝔼…[β(t)2∥𝐱^1(𝐱,t;θ)−𝐱1∥2+λ(t)2∥ϵ(𝐱,t;θ)−∇xlogpt(𝐱|𝐱1)∥2]\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{IDFF}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{...}\big{[}\beta(t)^{2}\|\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta)-{\mathbf{x}}_{1}\|^{2}+\lambda(t)^{2}\left\|\epsilon({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta)-\nabla_{x}\log p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})\right\|^{2}\big{]} (11)

Where {t∼𝒰​(0,1),𝐱0∼𝒩​(0,I),𝐱1∼pd​a​t​a,𝐱∼pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)}formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑡𝒰01formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝐱0𝒩0Iformulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝐱1subscript𝑝𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎similar-to𝐱subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1\{t\sim{\mathcal{U}}(0,1),{\mathbf{x}}_{0}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\textbf{I}),{\mathbf{x}}_{1}\sim p_{data},{\mathbf{x}}\sim p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})\}. Here {λ​(⋅),β​(⋅)}𝜆⋅𝛽⋅\{\lambda(\cdot),\beta(\cdot)\} are two sets of positive weights. See Appendix A.1.2 for more details about the loss function. The training process is described in Algorithm 1.

3.2 IDFF time-series adaptation and sampling process

To use IDFF for time-series applications, we need to modify the training and sampling algorithms for IDFF. To accomplish that, we define another random variable, k𝑘k, which is a discrete variable and can take values of {1,…,K}1…𝐾\{1,...,K\} with equal probability, where K𝐾K is the length of a time series. Therefore, k𝑘k represents the index of the data sample in a time series. We also have t𝑡t as a continuous time variable interpolated between two subsequent values of k𝑘k (i.e., k𝑘k and k−1𝑘1k-1). Therefore we have ∀k∈{1,…,K}→p​(t∣k)∼𝒰​(0,1)for-all𝑘1…𝐾→𝑝conditional𝑡𝑘similar-to𝒰01\forall k\in\{1,...,K\}\rightarrow p(t\mid k)\sim{\mathcal{U}}(0,1). This conditioning does not change the original assumption over t𝑡t since k𝑘k can take any values up to the time-series length with the sample probability. With this in hand, we can directly pass the k𝑘k as additional inputs to ϵ^1​(𝐱,t,k;θ)subscript^bold-italic-ϵ1𝐱𝑡𝑘𝜃\hat{\bm{\epsilon}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t,k;\theta) and 𝐱^1​(𝐱,t,k;θ)subscript^𝐱1𝐱𝑡𝑘𝜃\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t,k;\theta) and suggest Algorithm 1 for training and Algorithm 2 for sampling time-series data with IDFF. Note that for static data, the sequence length (K𝐾K) equals one; otherwise, it equals the time series length.

For a fixed K=1𝐾1K=1, once we have trained 𝐱^1(.;θ)\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}(.;\theta) and ϵ(.;θ)\bm{\epsilon}(.;\theta), we can generate samples simulated by an SDE from source samples 𝐱0subscript𝐱0{\mathbf{x}}_{0}. This procedure is outlined in Algorithm 2. The SDE is defined as d​𝐱t=𝐰t​(𝐱|𝐱1)​d​t+σt​d​𝐰𝑑subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1𝑑𝑡subscript𝜎𝑡𝑑𝐰d{\mathbf{x}}_{t}={\mathbf{w}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})dt+\sigma_{t}d\mathbf{w}, with initial samples 𝐱0subscript𝐱0{\mathbf{x}}_{0} and target samples 𝐱1subscript𝐱1{\mathbf{x}}_{1} at t=1𝑡1t=1. Therefore, we can draw samples from p​(𝐱0)𝑝subscript𝐱0p({\mathbf{x}}_{0}), run them through the SDE, and obtain the final samples 𝐱1subscript𝐱1{\mathbf{x}}_{1}.

First, we draw 𝐱0∼𝒩​(0,𝐈)similar-tosubscript𝐱0𝒩0𝐈{\mathbf{x}}_{0}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\mathbf{I}), then compute 𝐱^1​(𝐱,0,k;θ)subscript^𝐱1𝐱0𝑘𝜃\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},0,k;\theta). Next, we calculate 𝐯^tsubscript^𝐯𝑡\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t} using equation 10, followed by the computation of 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡{\mathbf{w}}_{t}. After calculating 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡{\mathbf{w}}_{t} and using the SDE, we compute the mean for the next time step as 𝝁t+Δ​t=(𝐱t+𝐰t​Δ​t)subscript𝝁𝑡Δ𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡Δ𝑡\bm{\mu}_{t+\Delta t}=({\mathbf{x}}_{t}+{\mathbf{w}}_{t}\Delta t), and finally draw a sample from a small neighborhood of it: 𝐱t+Δ​t∼𝒩​(𝐱t+𝐰t​Δ​t,σt2​Δ​t​𝐈)similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑡Δ𝑡𝒩subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐰𝑡Δ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑡2Δ𝑡𝐈{\mathbf{x}}_{t+\Delta t}\sim\mathcal{N}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}+{\mathbf{w}}_{t}\Delta t,\sigma_{t}^{2}\Delta t\mathbf{I}).

4 Related Work

Our proposed IDFF model extends state-of-the-art generative modeling techniques, particularly diffusion models such as denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) (Ho et al., 2020) and CFMs. DDPMs rely on SDEs and Langevin dynamics for sampling (Yan et al., 2021), while CFMs use deterministic ODE solvers to sample from learned vector fields. Both methods are effective at generating high-quality samples but require many iterations, leading to computational inefficiency.

To address these limitations, denoising diffusion implicit models (DDIMs)(Song et al., 2020b) were introduced, offering a more efficient sampling process by deterministically generating samples from latent variables. Unlike DDPMs, which rely on Langevin dynamics, DDIMs employ a variational approach that accelerates sampling while preserving output quality.

In the realm of CFMs, recent advancements include Schrödinger-based methods (Richter et al., 2023) and conjugate/splitting-based integrators (Pandey et al., 2023), which aim to improve sampling efficiency. However, these methods still struggle to significantly reduce the NFEs, a key factor for computational efficiency. Other approaches to enhance sampling in diffusion-based generative models include the generalized Schrodinger bridge, which seeks stochastic evolution between prior and target distributions (Richter et al., 2023), and distillation frameworks like Flash (Kohler et al., 2024), which offer diverse sample generation in fewer steps by addressing training-inference discrepancies.

IDFF builds upon these developments and introduces several key improvements. Rather than directly learning vector fields like CFMs, IDFF focuses on learning the evolving samples 𝒙tsubscript𝒙𝑡\bm{x}_{t} at each time step. It implicitly constructs the vector field during sampling through a reparameterization approach (Eq. 10). By incorporating a momentum term and a scoring model, IDFF allows for larger sampling steps, reducing NFE by up to a factor of 10 compared to CFMs, as illustrated in Figure 2.

A distinguishing feature of IDFF is its ability to jointly learn an implicit flow from the generated samples alongside the scoring model, setting it apart from models like DDIM, which focuses solely on learning a scoring function. By leveraging OT to couple samples between t=0𝑡0t=0 and t=1𝑡1t=1, IDFF accelerates convergence during training while maintaining low NFE and improving sample quality. It is evident from our image generation experiments (Tables 1 and 2). In comparisons with DDPM, DDIM, and DPM-Solver (another model that improves the NFEs for diffusion models)Lu et al. (2022a), IDFF consistently demonstrates superior efficiency and quality.

In conclusion, IDFF integrates the strengths of implicit flow and score-based learning, offering a novel and efficient framework for generative modeling that significantly reduces computational costs while producing high-quality samples.

5 Experiments

We conducted two general classes of experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of IDFF in generative modeling on static data, such as images and time-series data, including simulated chaotic systems (e.g., attractors), molecular dynamics, and sea surface temperature forecasting.

5.1 Image Generation

In this section, we showcase the superior performance of IDFF compared to CFMs in image generation, especially in the number of function evaluations (NFE). We trained IDFF models on datasets such as CIFAR-10 and CelebA (additional results for ImageNet-64, CelebA-HQ, LSUN Bedrooms, and LSUN Church are available in Appendix A.2). We utilized a CNN-based UNet (ADM) (Dhariwal and Nichol, 2021) to simultaneously model both 𝐱^1(.,t;θ)\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}(.,t;\theta) and ϵ(.,t;θ)\bm{\epsilon}(.,t;\theta) from Equation 11 for all image data except ImageNet-64. For ImageNet-64, we employed a DiT architecture (’DiT-L/4’)(Peebles and Xie, 2022). To implement this, we doubled the input channels of the networks and fed the augmented input, (𝐱t,𝐱t)subscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡({\mathbf{x}}_{t},{\mathbf{x}}_{t}), into the network. The outputs were then split into (𝐱^1(.,t;θ),ϵ(.,t;θ))(\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}(.,t;\theta),\bm{\epsilon}(.,t;\theta)).

To ensure a fair comparison with other models, we used commonly employed metrics to evaluate CFMs’ performance, including negative log-likelihood (NLL) measured in bits per dimension (BPD), sample quality as measured by the Frechet Inception Distance (FID), and the average NFE required for the reported FID and NLL, averaged over 50k samples, to assess the computational efficiency of our method. We generate 50k images to calculate the FID against the corresponding reference statistics of each dataset. All models use the same architecture, with specific details provided in Appendix A.1.4.

We also examined the effect of σ0subscript𝜎0\sigma_{0} on sample quality for both CIFAR-10 and CelebA datasets in Appendix A.1.3, finding that a value of σ0=0.6subscript𝜎00.6\sigma_{0}=0.6 achieved the best FID for both datasets, as shown in Table 1 and Table 2. IDFF achieves comparable FID scores with ten times fewer NFEs than CFM and DDPM on the CIFAR-10 and CelebA datasets. IDFF’s qualitative results are provided in Figure 1 (additional samples are available in Appendix A.2).

Figure 4 (A) displays the FID score for the initial 50k generated samples plotted against NFEs for both the CIFAR-10 and CelebA datasets. Sample quality improves rapidly when the NFE exceeds 4, highlighting the significantly lower sampling cost of IDFF compared to traditional CFMs and diffusion-based models.

5.2 Time Series Generation

To assess the performance of IDFF in modeling time series data, we evaluated IDFF on three distinct tasks: 3D-attractor generation (see Appendix A.3), molecular dynamics simulation, and sea surface temperature forecasting.

5.2.1 Molecular Dynamics Simulation

Molecular dynamics simulation is a crucial tool in quantum mechanics for understanding the dynamics of molecular behavior at the atomic level (Cazorla and Boronat, 2017). Here, we simulated a fully extended polyalanine structure for 400 picoseconds in a vacuum environment at a temperature of T=300​K𝑇300𝐾T=300K.

This molecular structure consists of 253 atoms with 46 dihedral angles. We trained an IDFF model to accurately generate the dihedral angles for the polyalanine structure from scratch. The distributions of the actual and generated dihedral angles for all 46 angles are presented in Figure 3 (A) and (B), respectively. Figure 3 (C) illustrates the dihedral angles for one of the alanine molecules and its associated dihedral angles. A complete trajectory showcasing a pair of actual and generated dihedral angles is depicted in Figure 3 (D).

To assess the performance of IDFF in the MD simulation, we utilized several evaluation metrics, including root mean squared error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), and correlation coefficients (CC) between the generated and actual trajectories of dihedral angles. We benchmarked IDFF against well-known dynamical models for time series, including dynamical VAE models such as SRNNs (Fraccaro et al., 2016), VRNNs (Chung et al., 2015), and Neural ODEs (NODEs) (Garnelo et al., 2018). As shown in Table 3, IDFF outperforms the baselines by a large margin, indicating its great potential for simulating molecular dynamics from scratch.

5.2.2 Sea Surface Temperature Forecasting

This experiment focuses on forecasting sea surface temperature (SST). Based on NOAA OISSTv2, our dataset consists of daily weather images with high-resolution SST data from 1982 to 2021 (Cachay et al., 2023). We created a refined dataset for forecasting SST intervals from 1 to 7 days ahead by strategically subsampling eleven grid tiles of size 60×60606060\times 60 (latitude ×\times longitude) in the eastern tropical Pacific region (Huang et al., 2021).

We used a class-conditional UNet (ADM) for the SST experiment, with the class encoder part encoding the long-range time dependencies (i.e., for encoding the days) to allow continuous forecasting using the UNet (ADM). See Appendix A.1.4 for the experiment’s network structure and hyperparameter settings. We used the training 1 and sampling 2 algorithms suggested for time-series data. We evaluated the performance of IDFF using the best validation continuous ranked probability score (CRPS) (Matheson and Winkler, 1976) and mean squared error (MSE) on forecasts up to 7 days. CRPS is a proper scoring rule and a popular metric in probabilistic forecasting literature (Gneiting and Katzfuss, 2014). We calculate the CRPS by generating a 20-member ensemble and the MSE on the ensemble mean predictions in Table 4. To assess IDFF’s performance, we compared it against various baseline approaches, including DDPM, DDPM with enabled dropout (Dropout) (Gal and Ghahramani, 2016), DDPM with random perturbation for the initial values (Perturbation) (Pathak et al., 2022), MCVD (Voleti et al., 2022), Dyffusion (Cachay et al., 2023), and OT-CFM (with N​F​E=40𝑁𝐹𝐸40NFE=40) as shown in Table 4. The results for all the baselines are with N​F​E=1000𝑁𝐹𝐸1000NFE=1000. These baselines provide a robust framework for evaluating the IDFF framework in time-series forecasting. For more details about the SST dataset and experiment, refer to (Cachay et al., 2023). The results show that IDFF (with N​F​E=5𝑁𝐹𝐸5NFE=5) outperforms the baselines in SST forecasting across both metrics, demonstrating great potential for weather forecasting applications. See samples of the forecasting results in Figure 13.

6 Conclusion

IDFF models represent a significant advancement in generative modeling, particularly for time series data, by offering superior computational efficiency compared to traditional flow models like CFMs. The enhanced efficiency and favorable trade-offs between computational cost and sample quality make IDFF a top choice for tasks requiring efficient and high-quality sample generation. Furthermore, IDFF has the potential to extend to other domains, such as music generation (Briot et al., 2017), speech synthesis (Yu and Deng, 2016), and the generation of noisy biological time-series data (Anumanchipalli et al., 2019; Golshan et al., 2020).

One limitation of IDFF pertains to the definition of OT plans, where the computational cost escalates with batch size, resulting in longer training times, especially for large batches. Additionally, while the ADM structure was primarily employed in our experiments, generating large-scale time series data, such as videos, could benefit from utilizing more recent backbone structures as proposed in (Ho et al., 2022; Peebles and Xie, 2023) to enhance efficiency further.

Broader Impacts and Limitations.

IDFF models offer a computationally efficient alternative to traditional flow models like CFMs, enabling faster generation of high-quality samples. This efficiency makes them practical for various applications, suggesting that IDFF could become a preferred choice for generative modeling tasks that demand both efficiency and high sample quality at a lower computational cost. However, it is crucial to establish safeguards and incentives to prevent the misuse of this technology. Care must be taken to ensure that the synthetic data generated by this technology is used following societal norms and ethical standards.

Moreover, IDFF could have broader implications across various fields and should be considered a generic framework that can extend applications such as music generation (Briot et al., 2017), speech generation (Yu and Deng, 2016), and other forms of noisy biological time-series data (Rezaei et al., 2021, 2023; Anumanchipalli et al., 2019; Golshan et al., 2020; Gracco et al., 2005).

  • Rezaei et al. [2021] Mohammad Reza Rezaei, Kensuke Arai, Loren M Frank, Uri T Eden, and Ali Yousefi. Real-time point process filter for multidimensional decoding problems using mixture models. Journal of neuroscience methods, 348:109006, 2021.
  • Rezaei et al. [2023] Mohammad R Rezaei, Haseul Jeoung, Ayda Gharamani, Utpal Saha, Venkat Bhat, Milos R Popovic, Ali Yousefi, Robert Chen, and Milad Lankarany. Inferring cognitive state underlying conflict choices in verbal stroop task using heterogeneous input discriminative-generative decoder model. Journal of Neural Engineering, 20(5):056016, 2023.
  • Gracco et al. [2005] Vincent L Gracco, Pascale Tremblay, and Bruce Pike. Imaging speech production using fmri. Neuroimage, 26(1):294–301, 2005.
  • Jolicoeur-Martineau et al. [2020] Alexia Jolicoeur-Martineau, Rémi Piché-Taillefer, Rémi Tachet des Combes, and Ioannis Mitliagkas. Adversarial score matching and improved sampling for image generation. arXiv preprint arXiv:2009.05475, 2020.
  • Jain et al. [2020] Ajay Jain, Pieter Abbeel, and Deepak Pathak. Locally masked convolution for autoregressive models. In Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence, pages 1358–1367. PMLR, 2020.

NeurIPS Paper Checklist

  1. 1.

    Claims

  2. Question: Do the main claims made in the abstract and introduction accurately reflect the paper’s contributions and scope?

  3. Answer: [Yes]

  4. Justification: The paper provides evidence for all the claims made in the abstract mainly in the experiments section.

  5. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the abstract and introduction do not include the claims made in the paper.

    • •

      The abstract and/or introduction should clearly state the claims made, including the contributions made in the paper and important assumptions and limitations. A No or NA answer to this question will not be perceived well by the reviewers.

    • •

      The claims made should match theoretical and experimental results, and reflect how much the results can be expected to generalize to other settings.

    • •

      It is fine to include aspirational goals as motivation as long as it is clear that these goals are not attained by the paper.

  6. 2.

    Limitations

  7. Question: Does the paper discuss the limitations of the work performed by the authors?

  8. Answer: [Yes]

  9. Justification: See the conclusion section

  10. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the paper has no limitation while the answer No means that the paper has limitations, but those are not discussed in the paper.

    • •

      The authors are encouraged to create a separate "Limitations" section in their paper.

    • •

      The paper should point out any strong assumptions and how robust the results are to violations of these assumptions (e.g., independence assumptions, noiseless settings, model well-specification, asymptotic approximations only holding locally). The authors should reflect on how these assumptions might be violated in practice and what the implications would be.

    • •

      The authors should reflect on the scope of the claims made, e.g., if the approach was only tested on a few datasets or with a few runs. In general, empirical results often depend on implicit assumptions, which should be articulated.

    • •

      The authors should reflect on the factors that influence the performance of the approach. For example, a facial recognition algorithm may perform poorly when image resolution is low or images are taken in low lighting. Or a speech-to-text system might not be used reliably to provide closed captions for online lectures because it fails to handle technical jargon.

    • •

      The authors should discuss the computational efficiency of the proposed algorithms and how they scale with dataset size.

    • •

      If applicable, the authors should discuss possible limitations of their approach to address problems of privacy and fairness.

    • •

      While the authors might fear that complete honesty about limitations might be used by reviewers as grounds for rejection, a worse outcome might be that reviewers discover limitations that aren’t acknowledged in the paper. The authors should use their best judgment and recognize that individual actions in favor of transparency play an important role in developing norms that preserve the integrity of the community. Reviewers will be specifically instructed to not penalize honesty concerning limitations.

  11. 3.

    Theory Assumptions and Proofs

  12. Question: For each theoretical result, does the paper provide the full set of assumptions and a complete (and correct) proof?

  13. Answer: [Yes]

  14. Justification: We provided proof for our method.

  15. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the paper does not include theoretical results.

    • •

      All the theorems, formulas, and proofs in the paper should be numbered and cross-referenced.

    • •

      All assumptions should be clearly stated or referenced in the statement of any theorems.

    • •

      The proofs can either appear in the main paper or the supplemental material, but if they appear in the supplemental material, the authors are encouraged to provide a short proof sketch to provide intuition.

    • •

      Inversely, any informal proof provided in the core of the paper should be complemented by formal proofs provided in appendix or supplemental material.

    • •

      Theorems and Lemmas that the proof relies upon should be properly referenced.

  16. 4.

    Experimental Result Reproducibility

  17. Question: Does the paper fully disclose all the information needed to reproduce the main experimental results of the paper to the extent that it affects the main claims and/or conclusions of the paper (regardless of whether the code and data are provided or not)?

  18. Answer: [Yes]

  19. Justification: See the experiment and method sections.

  20. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.

    • •

      If the paper includes experiments, a No answer to this question will not be perceived well by the reviewers: Making the paper reproducible is important, regardless of whether the code and data are provided or not.

    • •

      If the contribution is a dataset and/or model, the authors should describe the steps taken to make their results reproducible or verifiable.

    • •

      Depending on the contribution, reproducibility can be accomplished in various ways. For example, if the contribution is a novel architecture, describing the architecture fully might suffice, or if the contribution is a specific model and empirical evaluation, it may be necessary to either make it possible for others to replicate the model with the same dataset, or provide access to the model. In general. releasing code and data is often one good way to accomplish this, but reproducibility can also be provided via detailed instructions for how to replicate the results, access to a hosted model (e.g., in the case of a large language model), releasing of a model checkpoint, or other means that are appropriate to the research performed.

    • •

      While NeurIPS does not require releasing code, the conference does require all submissions to provide some reasonable avenue for reproducibility, which may depend on the nature of the contribution. For example

      1. (a)

        If the contribution is primarily a new algorithm, the paper should make it clear how to reproduce that algorithm.

      2. (b)

        If the contribution is primarily a new model architecture, the paper should describe the architecture clearly and fully.

      3. (c)

        If the contribution is a new model (e.g., a large language model), then there should either be a way to access this model for reproducing the results or a way to reproduce the model (e.g., with an open-source dataset or instructions for how to construct the dataset).

      4. (d)

        We recognize that reproducibility may be tricky in some cases, in which case authors are welcome to describe the particular way they provide for reproducibility. In the case of closed-source models, it may be that access to the model is limited in some way (e.g., to registered users), but it should be possible for other researchers to have some path to reproducing or verifying the results.

  21. 5.

    Open access to data and code

  22. Question: Does the paper provide open access to the data and code, with sufficient instructions to faithfully reproduce the main experimental results, as described in supplemental material?

  23. Answer: [Yes]

  24. Justification: Upon acceptance of the paper, we provided the GitHub repository enabling the reproduction of all the results presented in the paper.

  25. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that paper does not include experiments requiring code.

    • •

      Please see the NeurIPS code and data submission guidelines (https://nips.cc/public/guides/CodeSubmissionPolicy) for more details.

    • •

      While we encourage the release of code and data, we understand that this might not be possible, so “No” is an acceptable answer. Papers cannot be rejected simply for not including code, unless this is central to the contribution (e.g., for a new open-source benchmark).

    • •

      The instructions should contain the exact command and environment needed to run to reproduce the results. See the NeurIPS code and data submission guidelines (https://nips.cc/public/guides/CodeSubmissionPolicy) for more details.

    • •

      The authors should provide instructions on data access and preparation, including how to access the raw data, preprocessed data, intermediate data, and generated data, etc.

    • •

      The authors should provide scripts to reproduce all experimental results for the new proposed method and baselines. If only a subset of experiments are reproducible, they should state which ones are omitted from the script and why.

    • •

      At submission time, to preserve anonymity, the authors should release anonymized versions (if applicable).

    • •

      Providing as much information as possible in supplemental material (appended to the paper) is recommended, but including URLs to data and code is permitted.

  26. 6.

    Experimental Setting/Details

  27. Question: Does the paper specify all the training and test details (e.g., data splits, hyperparameters, how they were chosen, type of optimizer, etc.) necessary to understand the results?

  28. Answer: [Yes]

  29. Justification: The experiment section and appendices fully support this.

  30. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.

    • •

      The experimental setting should be presented in the core of the paper to a level of detail that is necessary to appreciate the results and make sense of them.

    • •

      The full details can be provided either with the code, in appendix, or as supplemental material.

  31. 7.

    Experiment Statistical Significance

  32. Question: Does the paper report error bars suitably and correctly defined or other appropriate information about the statistical significance of the experiments?

  33. Answer: [Yes]

  34. Justification: See the result tables 4, 3

  35. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.

    • •

      The authors should answer "Yes" if the results are accompanied by error bars, confidence intervals, or statistical significance tests, at least for the experiments that support the main claims of the paper.

    • •

      The factors of variability that the error bars are capturing should be clearly stated (for example, train/test split, initialization, random drawing of some parameter, or overall run with given experimental conditions).

    • •

      The method for calculating the error bars should be explained (closed form formula, call to a library function, bootstrap, etc.)

    • •

      The assumptions made should be given (e.g., Normally distributed errors).

    • •

      It should be clear whether the error bar is the standard deviation or the standard error of the mean.

    • •

      It is OK to report 1-sigma error bars, but one should state it. The authors should preferably report a 2-sigma error bar than state that they have a 96% CI, if the hypothesis of Normality of errors is not verified.

    • •

      For asymmetric distributions, the authors should be careful not to show in tables or figures symmetric error bars that would yield results that are out of range (e.g. negative error rates).

    • •

      If error bars are reported in tables or plots, The authors should explain in the text how they were calculated and reference the corresponding figures or tables in the text.

  36. 8.

    Experiments Compute Resources

  37. Question: For each experiment, does the paper provide sufficient information on the computer resources (type of compute workers, memory, time of execution) needed to reproduce the experiments?

  38. Answer: [Yes]

  39. Justification: See Table5

  40. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.

    • •

      The paper should indicate the type of compute workers CPU or GPU, internal cluster, or cloud provider, including relevant memory and storage.

    • •

      The paper should provide the amount of compute required for each of the individual experimental runs as well as estimate the total compute.

    • •

      The paper should disclose whether the full research project required more compute than the experiments reported in the paper (e.g., preliminary or failed experiments that didn’t make it into the paper).

  41. 9.

    Code Of Ethics

  42. Question: Does the research conducted in the paper conform, in every respect, with the NeurIPS Code of Ethics https://neurips.cc/public/EthicsGuidelines?

  43. Answer: [Yes]

  44. Justification: We reviewed the NeurIPS Code of Ethics.

  45. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the authors have not reviewed the NeurIPS Code of Ethics.

    • •

      If the authors answer No, they should explain the special circumstances that require a deviation from the Code of Ethics.

    • •

      The authors should make sure to preserve anonymity (e.g., if there is a special consideration due to laws or regulations in their jurisdiction).

  46. 10.

    Broader Impacts

  47. Question: Does the paper discuss both potential positive societal impacts and negative societal impacts of the work performed?

  48. Answer: [Yes]

  49. Justification: The papers societal impacts are discussed in the last section of the paper.

  50. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that there is no societal impact of the work performed.

    • •

      If the authors answer NA or No, they should explain why their work has no societal impact or why the paper does not address societal impact.

    • •

      Examples of negative societal impacts include potential malicious or unintended uses (e.g., disinformation, generating fake profiles, surveillance), fairness considerations (e.g., deployment of technologies that could make decisions that unfairly impact specific groups), privacy considerations, and security considerations.

    • •

      The conference expects that many papers will be foundational research and not tied to particular applications, let alone deployments. However, if there is a direct path to any negative applications, the authors should point it out. For example, it is legitimate to point out that an improvement in the quality of generative models could be used to generate deepfakes for disinformation. On the other hand, it is not needed to point out that a generic algorithm for optimizing neural networks could enable people to train models that generate Deepfakes faster.

    • •

      The authors should consider possible harms that could arise when the technology is being used as intended and functioning correctly, harms that could arise when the technology is being used as intended but gives incorrect results, and harms following from (intentional or unintentional) misuse of the technology.

    • •

      If there are negative societal impacts, the authors could also discuss possible mitigation strategies (e.g., gated release of models, providing defenses in addition to attacks, mechanisms for monitoring misuse, mechanisms to monitor how a system learns from feedback over time, improving the efficiency and accessibility of ML).

  51. 11.

    Safeguards

  52. Question: Does the paper describe safeguards that have been put in place for responsible release of data or models that have a high risk for misuse (e.g., pretrained language models, image generators, or scraped datasets)?

  53. Answer: [N/A]

  54. Justification: The paper presents a methodological approach to learning diffusion models. It is not instantiated on problems with very large datasets such as ImageNet and ThePile.

  55. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the paper poses no such risks.

    • •

      Released models that have a high risk for misuse or dual-use should be released with necessary safeguards to allow for controlled use of the model, for example by requiring that users adhere to usage guidelines or restrictions to access the model or implementing safety filters.

    • •

      Datasets that have been scraped from the Internet could pose safety risks. The authors should describe how they avoided releasing unsafe images.

    • •

      We recognize that providing effective safeguards is challenging, and many papers do not require this, but we encourage authors to take this into account and make a best faith effort.

  56. 12.

    Licenses for existing assets

  57. Question: Are the creators or original owners of assets (e.g., code, data, models), used in the paper, properly credited and are the license and terms of use explicitly mentioned and properly respected?

  58. Answer: [Yes]

  59. Justification: All datasets used from other sources are properly referenced in the paper.

  60. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the paper does not use existing assets.

    • •

      The authors should cite the original paper that produced the code package or dataset.

    • •

      The authors should state which version of the asset is used and, if possible, include a URL.

    • •

      The name of the license (e.g., CC-BY 4.0) should be included for each asset.

    • •

      For scraped data from a particular source (e.g., website), the copyright and terms of service of that source should be provided.

    • •

      If assets are released, the license, copyright information, and terms of use in the package should be provided. For popular datasets, paperswithcode.com/datasets has curated licenses for some datasets. Their licensing guide can help determine the license of a dataset.

    • •

      For existing datasets that are re-packaged, both the original license and the license of the derived asset (if it has changed) should be provided.

    • •

      If this information is not available online, the authors are encouraged to reach out to the asset’s creators.

  61. 13.

    New Assets

  62. Question: Are new assets introduced in the paper well documented and is the documentation provided alongside the assets?

  63. Answer: [Yes]

  64. Justification: The experiment section provides details of the datasets and experiments. Additionally, model details are also provided in appendix A.1.4.

  65. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the paper does not release new assets.

    • •

      Researchers should communicate the details of the dataset/code/model as part of their submissions via structured templates. This includes details about training, license, limitations, etc.

    • •

      The paper should discuss whether and how consent was obtained from people whose asset is used.

    • •

      At submission time, remember to anonymize your assets (if applicable). You can either create an anonymized URL or include an anonymized zip file.

  66. 14.

    Crowdsourcing and Research with Human Subjects

  67. Question: For crowdsourcing experiments and research with human subjects, does the paper include the full text of instructions given to participants and screenshots, if applicable, as well as details about compensation (if any)?

  68. Answer: [N/A]

  69. Justification: We don’t have any human subject

  70. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the paper does not involve crowdsourcing nor research with human subjects.

    • •

      Including this information in the supplemental material is fine, but if the main contribution of the paper involves human subjects, then as much detail as possible should be included in the main paper.

    • •

      According to the NeurIPS Code of Ethics, workers involved in data collection, curation, or other labor should be paid at least the minimum wage in the country of the data collector.

  71. 15.

    Institutional Review Board (IRB) Approvals or Equivalent for Research with Human Subjects

  72. Question: Does the paper describe potential risks incurred by study participants, whether such risks were disclosed to the subjects, and whether Institutional Review Board (IRB) approvals (or an equivalent approval/review based on the requirements of your country or institution) were obtained?

  73. Answer: [N/A]

  74. Justification: We don’t have any human subject

  75. Guidelines:

    • •

      The answer NA means that the paper does not involve crowdsourcing nor research with human subjects.

    • •

      Depending on the country in which research is conducted, IRB approval (or equivalent) may be required for any human subjects research. If you obtained IRB approval, you should clearly state this in the paper.

    • •

      We recognize that the procedures for this may vary significantly between institutions and locations, and we expect authors to adhere to the NeurIPS Code of Ethics and the guidelines for their institution.

    • •

      For initial submissions, do not include any information that would break anonymity (if applicable), such as the institution conducting the review.

A.1.2 Training objective derivations

As described in Theorem 2 of [Lipman et al., 2022], the FM loss is defined as:

ℒFM​(θ)=𝔼t,𝐱1,pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)​‖𝐯t​(𝐱)−𝐯^t​(𝐱)‖2subscriptℒFM𝜃subscript𝔼𝑡subscript𝐱1subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1superscriptnormsubscript𝐯𝑡𝐱subscript^𝐯𝑡𝐱2\mathcal{L}_{\text{FM}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{t,{\mathbf{x}}_{1},p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})}\big{\|}{\mathbf{v}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}})-\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}})\big{\|}^{2} (12)

The CFM loss, as defined in equation 5, is equivalent to the FM loss up to a constant value, implying that ℒFM​(θ)=ℒCFM​(θ)subscriptℒFM𝜃subscriptℒCFM𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\text{FM}}(\theta)=\mathcal{L}_{\text{CFM}}(\theta). Based on this equivalence, we can express the training objective for approximating the vector field in equation 7, f^​(𝐱,t∣𝐱1,𝐱0;θ)^𝑓𝐱conditional𝑡subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱0𝜃\hat{f}({\mathbf{x}},t\mid{\mathbf{x}}_{1},{\mathbf{x}}_{0};\theta), as:

ℒIDFF1(θ)=𝔼…∥𝐯^t(𝐱∣𝐱1;θ)−𝐯t(𝐱|𝐱1)∥2\mathcal{L}_{\text{IDFF}}^{1}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{...}\big{\|}\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}\mid{\mathbf{x}}_{1};\theta)-{\mathbf{v}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})\big{\|}^{2} (13)

To recover unbiased samples, we replace u^(.)\hat{u}(.) with equation 10 and 𝐯^t​(𝐱|𝐱1,𝐱0)subscript^𝐯𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱0\hat{{\mathbf{v}}}_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1},{\mathbf{x}}_{0}) with equation 9, resulting in:

ℒIDFF1​(θ)=𝔼…​[‖𝐱^1​(𝐱,t;θ)−𝐱1−t−𝐱1−𝐱1−t‖2]superscriptsubscriptℒIDFF1𝜃subscript𝔼…delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript^𝐱1𝐱𝑡𝜃𝐱1𝑡subscript𝐱1𝐱1𝑡2\mathcal{L}_{\text{IDFF}}^{1}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{...}\bigg{[}\bigg{\|}\frac{\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta)-{\mathbf{x}}}{1-t}-\frac{{\mathbf{x}}_{1}-{\mathbf{x}}}{1-t}\bigg{\|}^{2}\bigg{]} (14)
=𝔼…​[β​(t)2​‖x^1​(𝐱,t;θ)−𝐱1‖2]absentsubscript𝔼…delimited-[]𝛽superscript𝑡2superscriptnormsubscript^𝑥1𝐱𝑡𝜃subscript𝐱12=\mathbb{E}_{...}\big{[}\beta(t)^{2}\big{\|}\hat{x}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta)-{\mathbf{x}}_{1}\big{\|}^{2}\big{]} (15)

where β​(t)=11−t𝛽𝑡11𝑡\beta(t)=\frac{1}{1-t}. Therefore, we have:

ℒIDFF1​(θ)=𝔼…​[β​(t)2​‖x^1​(𝐱,t;θ)−𝐱1‖2]superscriptsubscriptℒIDFF1𝜃subscript𝔼…delimited-[]𝛽superscript𝑡2superscriptnormsubscript^𝑥1𝐱𝑡𝜃subscript𝐱12\mathcal{L}_{\text{IDFF}}^{1}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{...}\big{[}\beta(t)^{2}\big{\|}\hat{x}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta)-{\mathbf{x}}_{1}\big{\|}^{2}\big{]} (16)

To approximate ∇xlog⁡pt​(𝐱|𝐱1)subscript∇𝑥subscript𝑝𝑡conditional𝐱subscript𝐱1\nabla_{x}\log p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}), we can employ a time-dependent score-based model, ϵ​(𝐱,t;θ)italic-ϵ𝐱𝑡𝜃\epsilon({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta), using a continuous loss function with a weighting schedule λ​(t)𝜆𝑡\lambda(t). Since ∇log⁡pt​(𝐱t|𝐱1)∇subscript𝑝𝑡conditionalsubscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝐱1\nabla\log p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}_{t}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1}) approaches infinity as t𝑡t tends to 0 or 1, it is necessary to standardize the loss to maintain consistency over time. We set λ​(t)𝜆𝑡\lambda(t) such that the target has zero mean and unit variance, predicting the noise added in sampling xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} before multiplying by σt=σ0​t​(1−t)subscript𝜎𝑡subscript𝜎0𝑡1𝑡\sigma_{t}=\sigma_{0}t(1-t). This leads to λ​(t)=σt=σ0​t​(1−t)𝜆𝑡subscript𝜎𝑡subscript𝜎0𝑡1𝑡\lambda(t)=\sigma_{t}=\sigma_{0}t(1-t), ensuring that the regression target for ϵθsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃\epsilon_{\theta} is distributed as N​(0,1)𝑁01N(0,1). Notably, this loss function is independent of the γ𝛾\gamma value, allowing us to use the same model with different γ𝛾\gamma values during the sampling process without altering the minima. The loss is defined as:

ℒIDFF2(θ)=𝔼…[λ(t)2∥ϵ(𝐱,t;θ)−∇xlogpt(𝐱|𝐱1)∥2]\mathcal{L}_{\text{IDFF}}^{2}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{...}\big{[}\lambda(t)^{2}\left\|\epsilon({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta)-\nabla_{x}\log p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})\right\|^{2}\big{]} (17)

where λ​(⋅)𝜆⋅\lambda(\cdot) is a set of positive weights. With a proper choice of λ​(t)𝜆𝑡\lambda(t), this loss is equivalent to the original DDPM loss up to a constant value, according to Theorem 1 of [Song et al., 2020b].

Combining the two components, the IDFF loss function is defined as:

ℒIDFF​(θ)=ℒIDFF1​(θ)+ℒIDFF2​(θ)subscriptℒIDFF𝜃superscriptsubscriptℒIDFF1𝜃superscriptsubscriptℒIDFF2𝜃\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{IDFF}}(\theta)=\mathcal{L}_{\text{IDFF}}^{1}(\theta)+\mathcal{L}_{\text{IDFF}}^{2}(\theta) (18)

Which leads to the final objective function:

ℒIDFF(θ)=𝔼…[β(t)2∥𝐱^1(𝐱,t;θ)−𝐱1∥2+λ(t)2∥ϵ(𝐱,t;θ)−∇xlogpt(𝐱|𝐱1)∥2]\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{IDFF}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{...}\big{[}\beta(t)^{2}\|\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta)-{\mathbf{x}}_{1}\|^{2}+\lambda(t)^{2}\left\|\epsilon({\mathbf{x}},t;\theta)-\nabla_{x}\log p_{t}({\mathbf{x}}|{\mathbf{x}}_{1})\right\|^{2}\big{]} (19)

A.1.3 Balancing the IDFF flow

IDFF consists of a scoring model and an implicit flow component coupled with a parameter σ0subscript𝜎0\sigma_{0} to generate flow 𝐰(.)\bm{{\mathbf{w}}}(.). We examine the effect of σ0subscript𝜎0\sigma_{0} on sample quality for the CIFAR-10 and CelebA datasets, with the NFE fixed at 10. As shown in Figure 4 (B), a value of σ0=0.6subscript𝜎00.6\sigma_{0}=0.6 achieves the best balance between the diffusion and flow components regarding sample quality for both datasets. This plot also demonstrates that sample quality is susceptible to σ0subscript𝜎0\sigma_{0}, particularly for diffusion-based models like DDPMs, compared to CFMs, especially at small NFEs, which is already noticed in some research[Jolicoeur-Martineau et al., 2020, Jain et al., 2020].

A.1.4 Implementation details

Network configuration: We adopt UNet (ADM) for our image generation and SST forecasting experiments. Table 5 shows detailed configurations of the ADM network on different datasets.

Training hyper-params. In Table 6, we provide training hyperparameters for unconditional image generation on ADM and SST forecasting datasets.

A.2 Additional results for image generation experiment

A.3 3D-attractors

In this experiment, we assess IDFF’s performance in generating trajectories of chaotic systems from scratch. We generate trajectories with K=2000𝐾2000K=2000 samples in each trajectory from 3D attractors, specifically the Lorenz and Rössler attractors, which are chaotic systems with nonlinear dynamics. The parameters for the Lorenz and Rössler models are set to σ=10,ρ=28,β=8/3formulae-sequence𝜎10formulae-sequence𝜌28𝛽83{\sigma=10,\rho=28,\beta=8/3} and a=.2,b=.2,c=5.7formulae-sequence𝑎.2formulae-sequence𝑏.2𝑐5.7{a=.2,b=.2,c=5.7}, respectively, to produce complex trajectories in 3D space. We then train the IDFF model based on these trajectories. To model each attractor, we use an MLP with two hidden layers of 128 dimensions and two separate heads for 𝐱^1(.,t,k;θ)\hat{{\mathbf{x}}}_{1}(.,t,k;\theta) and ϵ​(𝐱,t,k;θ)italic-ϵ𝐱𝑡𝑘𝜃\epsilon({\mathbf{x}},t,k;\theta). Additionally, we incorporate two separate embedding layers for embedding t𝑡t and k𝑘k, which are directly concatenated with the first hidden layer of the MLP. The optimized IDFF successfully generates samples of these trajectories from scratch. The generated trajectories are shown in Figure 12. The quality of the results demonstrates that IDFF can successfully simulate the behaviors of highly nonlinear and nonstationary systems such as attractors.
